Award.AwardTitle: Activity-dependent development of the glial network in Drosophila ventral nerve cord
Award.AbstractNarration:
Glial cells are non-electrical brain cells that work together with neurons to make the nervous system function. Glial cells can sense the activity of neurons and control it, help to guide the wiring of the networks of neurons, are involved in learning and memory, and provide vital metabolic support for neurons, so mapping only the connections and activity of neurons in the brain is not enough to understand how the brain works. Glial cells must be included. This project will: (1) detail the anatomy of individual glial cells and make a comprehensive map of the glial cells and the network they form; and (2) examine the effect of disrupting neuronal activity on the development of glial cells and their network. The work will be carried out in the nervous system of the fruit fly Drosophila, a genetically powerful system in which development and function of neurons have been well studied. Because Drosophila shares many aspects of cellular development with humans, an understanding of the developmental relationship between neurons and glial cells in this advantageous model system will lead toward a fuller understanding of normal development and mature functioning of the human brain. The project also includes outreach to the public via K-12 classroom visits and public events, and a multi-station hands-on Brain booth at a large annual festival. Several undergraduate students each year will be trained in the laboratory. A new course for undergraduates about glial cells will be developed that will include creation of a website on glial cells that will serve as a resource for the academic community.

This project will examine the hypothesis that the glial network is shaped by neuronal activity during development. The work will be carried out in the ventral nerve cord of the 3rd-instar Drosophila larva. Previous work has developed this system to specifically address neuron development, but the developing glial network in this system has not been characterized. Thus, this is a particularly advantageous animal model ripe for investigating the effects of neuron activity on glial development. The project will provide a high-resolution reconstruction of the glial network in the ventral nerve cord using genetically labeled and dye-filled glial cells, electron microscopy, and 3D reconstruction of glial cells in normally developing animals and in animals in which neuronal activity in the nerve cord has been blocked or reduced using genetic manipulations during larval development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Glial cells are the second major class of cells in the brain, with at least as many glial cells as nerve cells in the human brain. They are the source of most brain tumors and they now are known to be critical players in development and in functioning of the normal brain. Increasingly they are seen to contribute to disorders of the nervous system.  It behooves us then to better understand them. 

We know that glial cells affect nerve cell function through molecular signals that move between the two cell types. The spatial relationships between the cells is crucial in that signaling process. In this project, we used the nervous system of the genetically powerful fruit fly larva to study the network of glial cells in the central nervous system.  Our goal was to determine how that network is organized relative to the nerve cell circuitry and to determine the consequences of blocking neuronal signals on the development of the glial network.  We used genetic techniques that allowed us to put fluorescent labels of different colors into glial cells so that we could analyze the shapes of individual glia, determine what territory each one covers in the brain, whether they overlap each other, and whether they are distributed in ways that map to particular neuronal circuits.

Because we knew from experiments in which we recorded electrical activity from both nerve cells and glial cells that the two cell classes communicate with other, we also chronically blocked activity in the nerve cells during early stages of development. This allowed us to ask whether altering the conversation between the two classes would affect development of the glial cells.  We used the same approaches described earlier to analyze the effect.

We also examined high power images from the electron microscope to study the spatial relationship between glial cells and nerve cell synapses, the contact points for communication between two nerve cells.  We now have high resolution, high detail images and reconstructions of the glial network to add to data collected in other labs about the neuronal circuitry in this powerful experimental system.  Our data, coupled with glial data from other labs, indicate that fruit fly glial cells share many features with vertebrate glial cells, meaning that they can be used profitably to study glial cell function and disorders

From the perspective of broader impacts, I have made numerous classroom visits (grades 2-8), served as a co-director for the Brainworks booth at the Tucson Festival of Books Science City (~2000 visitors to our booth, 14 hand-on demos about the brain) for the last 7 years, served as a founding member of the Brain Bus Project (to develop a mobile outreach vehicle that support education about the brain to children and the general public in So. AZ; Fig. 2), and developed with a colleague (Dr. Leslie Tolbert) an upper-division course on glial cells for the undergraduate program in Neuroscience and Cognitive Science (2nd offering just completed).  We also have trained 1 graduate student as well as 8 undergraduate students and 1 high school student in the lab. Six of those undergraduate students contributed at a high level to the work on this project and have been or shortly will be co-authors on the peer-reviewed papers resulting from this project.  They also attended one or more of the Society for Neuroscience meetings and presented posters there.
